program, short of its
abolishment.

released after receiving written
request from the student and the
institution to which he's
applying."

Colonel Serena to resign at end of spring semester
By JAY S. GOODGOLD
Colonel Robert Serena will
resign as Head Counselor in the
Alumni Memorial Residences at
the end of spring semester.
However, he will retain his job
as intramural director in the
athletic department. Aside from
that, he advises several Hopkins
organizations, including the
Flying and Karate Clubs, as well
as the organization of all the
athletic events on the campus.
"I'm going to stay with my job
up here" Serena said. "It keeps
me busy."
Announcing his decision at
this week's Housemasters'
meeting, Serena cited personal
reasons for his resignation. He
and Dean of Students Robert J.
Fitzpatrick have not yet
discussed possible successors.
Fitzpatrick said that he was
looking for someone with
previous experience in counselling
to take over the Colonel's job.
Fantastic Job.
"He (Serena) has done a
fantastic job. It's a 24 hour a day
job, and he's been great at it,"
said Fitzpatrick. "He's personally
seen a whole generation of
students conic and go," he
added.
Before leaving his post as head
resident counselor, Serena said he
hopes to implement some new
services. First he said that an Arts
& Crafts room in the dormitory
basement is to be set up. "It'll be
good to do something with your
hands," he commented. He
hoped that it would be ready by

the beginning of the second
semester, and may be opened by
Thanksgiving.
Serena also noted that he was
trying to set up a dark room in
the dorm basement, and find
some space around the campus
where, he said, "the kids could
repair their cars without doing it
in the streets."
"Since Dean Fitzpatrick came
around there seems to be more
money available," said Serena.
"He has helped quite a bit-it's
money that we never got
before," he added.
Spring Cleaning
Reminiscing about his years in
the dorms, Serena said "They've
been great years for me." Asked
what was the most "dramatic"
event he had experienced at the
dorms, he pointed out the
narcotics raid by city police three
and a half years ago.
"The Police had search and
seizure warrants for him (the
pusher) and then hit the
campus." The Colonel continued,
"There was a good aspect to it; it
was the best spring cleaning
we've had on campus."
Serena said that his most
humorous experience on campus
was one which occurred right
after the bust.
"I came out of my quarters
one morning and found a little
old marijuana plant for me in my
garden. I went back inside and
got my sprinkler and watered the
plant. For ten weeks I watered it,
and it grew three feet. Then
someone dug it up one morning."

Serena was a graduate student
at Hopkins in 1939-1940,
majoring in Psychology, while
also being the freshman
basketball and football coach, as
well as being the first full-time
director of intramural activities
here. During his first year, he was
asked to serve as head resident
counselor in the dorms after the
school decided to separate the
freshmen in the dorms from the
upperclassmen living there.

press vs. White House

By ALAN HIRSCH
"The White House and the
Press" will be the topic of the
Frank R. Kent Symposium at
Hopkins, March 6 and 7. The
, Symposium will concern the role
of the press in relation to the
White House.
A bequest several years ago by
Frank R. Kent established the
endowed lectureship. Though not
too specifically defined,
programs of the lectureship are
supposed to be in some way
related to the Press, revealed one
of this year's symposium
organizers, Dr. J. Woodford,
Howard, Political Science.
The late Washington
correspondent for Baltimore Sun,
Kent was pioneer in .investigative
reporting," according to the
symposium's coordinator Michael
Nelson, a grad student.
Speakers slated to deliver
lectures at the symposium
include Marquis E.' Childs,
nationally syndicated columnist,
Douglass Cater, former editOr of
The Reporter, Adam Clymer, the
Sun's current White House
correspondent, and Ben
Bagdikian, a freelance writer
formerly associated with The
Washington Post.
In addition to these four
speakers, a foreign journalist yet.
to be selected, will also speak.
All five lectures in the
symposium will be given during
the two days in March.
"The symposium will be
intensive, instead of spread out,
like the Eisenhower
Symposium," commented
Nelson.
Childs will keynote the

symposium, delivering an
overview of the relation between
the White House and the press.
Cater, author of the book The
Fourth Branch, which discusses
the press' role as another branch
of the government, will examine
•the White House -Press
relationship from the White
House perspective.
Clymer, described by Nelson
as "one of the best men in his
field today," will consider the
White House-Press relationship
from the point of view of the
press. Bagdikian will present the
"Middle American" view of the
relationship between the two.
The foreign journalist yet to
be decided upon, but who will
very likely be from the London
Times, will give a foreigner's
perspective of the White House
and the press, revealed Nelson.
"Correspondents in
Washington may tend to
overemphasize the White House's
significance in the over-all scope
of world affairs," said Nelson."A
foreigner may add sonic external
objectivity," he added.
"The symposium's topic is
extremely relevant not only to
the past year's events, but it is
• also relevant to the work of
Frank Kent," continued Nelson.
"Kent was the leadin.g
journalist of his day when it
came to practical political
matters," he asserted.
Interest earned on Kent's
lectureship endowment several
years ago provides the funds for
the symposium. This is the first
time in several years the
lectureship endowment has.heen
employed.

It took the Student Council seven weeks, but it finally managed to write and pass a final version of the student discipline
code. Calling for an initial hearing either by a hearing board
composed of members of the campus community, or by the
Dean of Students with appeal to a hearing board, the proposed
code now goes to the Homewood Advisory Council, where we
hope it will die a quick and total death. For this code is just the
latest in a long series of ill-conceived, sloppily drawn and irresponsible discipline proposals advanced here over the past three
years.
Starting with the now infamous Benton code promulgated by
Dr. George S. Benton when he was Dean of Arts and Sciences
three years ago, and culminating Tuesday in the SC action on
the most recent guidelines, every proposal advanced has suffered the same major flaw -- the student has no defense against arbitrary and capricious acts on the' part of University authorities.
The provision of the code which allows either the University
or the student to remove any of the randomly chosen members
of the hearing board renders absurd whdt is supposed to be a
fair and impartial process. For if the University, in time of crisis, should decide to hamstring its own judicial system by simply removing every member of the board, the discipline process
would come to a halt, and the student involved would have no
recourse. To be sure, a student involved in a disciplinary procedure could accomplish the same end by removing every panel
member to whom he objected and the University would then be
stuck. Neither prospect is encouraging.
More important than either of the points mentioned earlier,
however, is the fact that no code would have any validity whatever if the Board of Trustees, as the ultimate legal authority of
the University, should decide to suspend it during some crisis.
The only way students can be reasonably assured this will not
occur is if the Trustees delegate to the Dean of Students and the
individually constituted hearing board final authority to deal
with all discipline matters. Until this unlikely event occurs, it is
pointless even to bother with the drafting of a code of disciplinary procedures. Until such delegation is forthcoming, the SC
.would serve itself better by moving on to other matters.

Colonel Serena to resign at end of spring semester

Colonel Robert Serena will
resign as Head Counselor in the

However, he will retain his job
as intramural director in the
athletic department. Aside from
that, he advises several Hopkins
organizations, including the

as the organization of all the
athletic events on the campus.
"I'm going to stay with my job

me busy."

meeting, Serena cited personal
reasons for his resignation. He
and Dean of Students Robert J.
Fitzpatrick have not yet
discussed possible successors.
Fitzpatrick said that he was
looking for someone with
previous experience in counselling
to take over the Colonel's job.
Fantastic Job.
"He (Serena) has done a
fantastic job. It's a 24 hour a day
job, and he's been great at it,"
said Fitzpatrick. "He's personally
seen a whole generation of
students conic and go," he
added.
Before leaving his post as head
resident counselor, Serena said he
hopes to implement some new
services. First he said that an Arts
& Crafts room in the dormitory
basement is to be set up. "It'll be
good to do something with your
hands," he commented. He
hoped that it would be ready by

the beginning of the second
semester, and may be opened by
Thanksgiving.

trying to set up a dark room in
the dorm basement, and find
some space around the campus

repair their cars without doing it
in the streets."
"Since Dean Fitzpatrick came

money available," said Serena.
"He has helped quite a bit-it's
money that we never got
before," he added.
Spring Cleaning
Reminiscing about his years in
the dorms, Serena said "They've
been great years for me." Asked
what was the most "dramatic"
event he had experienced at the
dorms, he pointed out the
narcotics raid by city police three
and a half years ago.
"The Police had search and
seizure warrants for him (the
pusher) and then hit the
campus." The Colonel continued,
"There was a good aspect to it; it
was the best spring cleaning
we've had on campus."
Serena said that his most
humorous experience on campus
was one which occurred right
after the bust.
"I came out of my quarters
one morning and found a little
old marijuana plant for me in my
garden. I went back inside and
got my sprinkler and watered the
plant. For ten weeks I watered it,
and it grew three feet. Then
someone dug it up one morning."

majoring in Psychology, while
also being the freshman

director of intramural activities

asked to serve as head resident
counselor in the dorms after the

It took the Student Council seven weeks, but it finally managed to write and pass a final version of the student discipline
code. Calling for an initial hearing either by a hearing board
composed of members of the campus community, or by the
Dean of Students with appeal to a hearing board, the proposed
code now goes to the Homewood Advisory Council, where we
hope it will die a quick and total death. For this code is just the
latest in a long series of ill-conceived, sloppily drawn and irresponsible discipline proposals advanced here over the past three
years.
Starting with the now infamous Benton code promulgated by
Dr. George S. Benton when he was Dean of Arts and Sciences
three years ago, and culminating Tuesday in the SC action on
the most recent guidelines, every proposal advanced has suffered the same major flaw -- the student has no defense against arbitrary and capricious acts on the' part of University authorities.
The provision of the code which allows either the University
or the student to remove any of the randomly chosen members
of the hearing board renders absurd whdt is supposed to be a
fair and impartial process. For if the University, in time of crisis, should decide to hamstring its own judicial system by simply removing every member of the board, the discipline process
would come to a halt, and the student involved would have no
recourse. To be sure, a student involved in a disciplinary procedure could accomplish the same end by removing every panel
member to whom he objected and the University would then be
stuck. Neither prospect is encouraging.
More important than either of the points mentioned earlier,
however, is the fact that no code would have any validity whatever if the Board of Trustees, as the ultimate legal authority of
the University, should decide to suspend it during some crisis.
The only way students can be reasonably assured this will not
occur is if the Trustees delegate to the Dean of Students and the
individually constituted hearing board final authority to deal
with all discipline matters. Until this unlikely event occurs, it is
pointless even to bother with the drafting of a code of disciplinary procedures. Until such delegation is forthcoming, the SC
.would serve itself better by moving on to other matters.
